Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The team awaits a clarification before progressing with a shared task.
Situation2: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Story: I stood behind the register, scanning groceries for the next customer in line. The store was quiet, just a handful of people waiting, but my phone buzzed insistently in my pocket. I knew it was my team at the office, waiting for my response to a question that would let them move forward with our project. I could almost picture them, eyes on their screens, growing impatient as the minutes ticked by. At the same time, the customer in front of me smiled politely, expecting me to focus on ringing up her items and handling her payment without mistakes. My manager always reminded us that accuracy was everything—one wrong scan, and the till would be off at the end of the day. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between the responsibility to my colleagues and the duty to the customers in front of me. My hand hovered over the register, my mind racing with the knowledge that someone would be disappointed, no matter what I chose.
